biogHist.abstract: In 1989, Catherine Pirie became the first women of Torres Strait Islander decent to be admitted as a solicitor. She achieved another first in 2000 when she was appointed Magistrate; once again, the first Torres Strait Islander to hold the position.
biogHist.p: The oldest of six children, Catherin Pirie was born in Cairns, but the family soon moved to Garbutt in Townsville. Two of the six went on to be lawyers; Catherine and her brother, Kevin Smith. The children attended Catholic schools at both primary and secondary level; their fees paid through the assistance of their paternal grandparetns, Arthur and Hannah Smith.

After high school, Catherine travelled to the Queensland University of Technology in Brisbane to study law, although readily admits that the only knowleddge she had of the discipline was what she saw on television. Adjusting to study and life away from home was a daunting experience and by thrid year, she was ready to give up her studies. Fortunately, she was offered work at the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legal Service by solicitor Paul Richards, where she worked for a number of years in a variety of roles. She returned to her studies and graduated with a Bachelor of Laws in 1988. She married David Pirie, another lawyer, in 1990.

Since then, she and her husband have worked in Queensland and Western Australia in offices of the Aboriginal Legal Service in Townsville and Albany. She was appointed a magistrate, workign mainly in the Cairns region, in 2000, becoming the first Torres Strait Islander to hold a judicial position. It was a special day for her in July 2011 when she presided in the Magistrates Court at Thursday Island.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: 'Pirie, Catherine', in The Australian Women's Register, National Foundation for Australian Women and The University of Melbourne

bibseries.title: A Woman's Place: 100 Years of Queensland Women Lawyers
bibseries.name: Susan Purdon and Aladin Rahemtula
